intro: Oxypolis bakeri, commonly known as Baker's oxypolis, is a flowering plant native to specific regions of the western United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes plants like carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its umbel-shaped flower clusters. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and thrives in arid or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a slight pubescence, while its flowers range in color from white to pale yellow. Oxypolis bakeri is relatively rare and is of interest to botanists due to its limited distribution and unique ecological adaptations.
